awd_titl_txt: RUI: Analysis on HyperKahler Moduli Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
In many areas of geometry and physics, the collection of objects under investigation can be organized together to form a space with intrinsic geometry, known as a "moduli space". Moduli spaces may parameterize a wide variety of objects, from physical particles, to geometric shapes, to solutions of differential equations. They are important not only because they carry information about the objects they parameterize, but also because they represent naturally occurring examples of interesting geometries. There are several well-known families of moduli spaces which carry a so-called hyperKahler geometry, based on the algebra of quaternions, and physical considerations suggest that these moduli spaces may have certain strong properties reflected in their global shape, or topology. A principal goal of this project is to develop analytical tools to establish these properties and more deeply understand the geometry of these spaces and their relatives. This work has significant interdisciplinary appeal as it makes contact with several different areas of analysis, geometry and topology, and provides a testing ground for certain duality principles in physics. Additional impacts of the project include the facilitation of the PI's educational activities, including the supervising of original undergraduate research, mentoring student-led project-based independent study projects, and an ongoing initiative to improve diversity and gender parity in the mathematics program at New College of Florida.

This project will develop a framework for the analysis of elliptic operators on a class of spaces which includes several families of hyperKahler moduli spaces of interest in physics and geometry. These are exemplified by the moduli spaces of magnetic monopoles, the L2 cohomology of which is the subject of a long standing and still open conjecture of Ashoke Sen coming from supersymmetric physics. This seminal conjecture spawned several parallel conjectures about similar moduli spaces, and is the starting point for a number interesting geometric questions motivated by physics. A principal tool this project will develop is a generalization of Mazzeo and Melrose's well-known calculus of pseudodifferential operators on manifolds with "fibered boundary", to a category of compact manifolds with "quasi-fibered boundary". This is a category in which the monopole moduli spaces and other families of hyperKahler moduli spaces admit natural compactifications, the construction of which is a second major goal of this project. Beginning with a proof of Sen's conjecture, this work will therefore make refined techniques of geometric microlocal analysis newly available to the study of these important classes of spaces in hyperKahler geometry and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project contributed to a fuller understanding of several naturally occurring moduli spaces which admit a special geometric structure based on the quaternions (i.e., a hyperkahler metric). These spaces, which parameterize some other kind of geometric or physical objects such as point configurations or solutions to gauge-theoretic partial differential equations, lie at the intersection of physics, algebraic geometry, differential geometry, and topology, a setting that allows for many different perspectives from different disciplines to inform one another.

At issue for the present project was the detailed geometric structure "at infinity" in these spaces, and the precise restrictions this structure imposes on the growth of certain energy minimizing functions and their generalizations (i.e., harmonic differential forms).

In the most significant outcome of the project, the PI and his collaborator F. Rochon successfully developed a detailed framework for the analysis of elliptic operators with respect to a general class of metrics called quasi-fibered boundary, or QFB, metrics, which include in particular the hyperkahler examples of interest to the project. For these examples of interest, the authors were able to use their newly developed framework to obtain precise decay results for harmonic forms that were the key to making substantial progress on, and in one case completely resolving, longstanding conjectures coming from physics (Sen's conjecture for magnetic monopoles, and the Vafa-Witten conjecture for Hilbert schemes of points on C^2, respectively).

In supporting work, the authors also obtained detailed results about the low-energy limit of the spectrum (generalized frequencies of vibration) of fibered boundary metrics (which include asympototically flat spaces), which is notable as the opposite to the comparatively better studied high-energy, or "semiclassical", limit. In other supporting work, they developed key categorical properties of "fibered-corners" manifolds, a structure which underlies QFB metrics as well as the "iterated incomplete edge" (aka wedge) metrics that have received much attention in the analysis of stratified and singular spaces in recent decades.

The success of the analytical framework and supporting work developed in this project points toward several future applications in both the construction of, and analysis on, higher dimensional infinite volume spaces with special geometries.

Finally, in a separate collaboration on a different subject, the PI and R. Melrose developed the theory of "multigerbes", which are geometric objects which represent, in a precise sense, the topology (i.e., integer cohomology) of the spaces on which they live. Multigerbes comprise an appealing alternative to prior theories of higher gerbes as their defining conditions are easier to verify in practice and they enjoy naturally arising examples coming from string theory.

In addition to dissemination of the research results through seminar and conference talks as well as the public preprint repository arXiv, the broader impacts of this work stem largely from the PI's education and mentorship efforts at New College of Florida, a public honors undergraduate institution. The PI sponsored four senior undergraduate theses during the award period, with two of these students now in math PhD programs and one in a data science masters program. Some of the funds were used to bring an international visitor to campus to give a colloquium and guest lecture.
